environments/enable-secure-rbac.yaml.message: FWIW - I used https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance/+/810319 locally to generate the defaults. Otherwise oslopolicy-sample-generator broke with double quotes around community, public, and shared.
redundant*
This whole list is wrong as it was built from the broken RBAC patches and not the tip of the fixes.

is this intentional.

what are the implicaiton of checking is_admin:True vs role:admin or are they the same

The is_admin:True check is just a longer way of getting to role:'admin'. The is_admin:True check evaluates the is_admin property of the context object [0], which is ultimately set by context_is_admin [1] and defaults to only checking the admin role [2].

Since we're moving towards more granularity with administrative roles (e.g., ideally we want system-admins, domain-admins, and project-admins), I lean towards not using is_admin since it's doesn't relay anything about the scope unless you override the context_is_admin check. IME, using role:admin is more direct and clear until we get the scope-types integrated back in (or just using nova's defaults).

[0] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/context.py#L138
[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/policy.py#L218
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/policies/base.py#L88-L91
ok yes the keypairs are owned by the user not the project so you should not be able to see keypair that are not yours unless you an admin +1

we likely just want to have this be

      key: "project_admin_api"
      value: "rule:admin_api"

we can check the project matche if we want but with this set of override there is just a gloabl admin and it feels strnge to lock down the api we wanted to open up to project admin more then the purly admin only apis

so i would redefien project_admin_api as an alisa for admin_api

-1 is for this

Tobiko creates its resources by need/demand, i.e. if we don't use the resources in the test or they are not a dependency of other required resources, they will not be created.

I just checked to verify - in Active/standby case it will create an LB and stop there (as amphoras are being created only when an LB is being created).

ic, it looks like 'system health-query-upgrade' will just check for existence and expected size (10000 mib), but not free platform-backup space.

Sounds like we're back to square one. We need to document a reliable way for the users to check if /opt/platform-backup has enough space for the upgrade. John/David, can you confirm that removing old backups is a suitable instruction? I believe the backup files generated by the upgrade procedure is removed once upgrade is finalized but the users can perform one or more system backup between upgrades.

We don't currently have a process to determine the free space required in /opt/platform-backup.  Realistically the only thing a user can do is try the upgrade start. For now this recommendation can be to remove any unused files in /opt/platform-backup. Backups are not typically stored there, only the upgrade data.

environments/enable-secure-rbac.yaml.message:
Have we considered the operational maintenance cost for our development efforts and maintenance activities to continue use of specific service parameters through the THT templates to the puppet manifests?

It seems like were going to have to land number_of_puppet_modules * 2 as a minimum number of changes by taking any other path than a single central path. That number of patches has a huge cost in resources, both electronic and human.

Maybe there is a value I'm not seeing? In other words, I think this is the right path and maybe the simpler path is to begin to rework config injection/management through this path. If we feel projects don't ship sane defaults which we override in the puppet modules, then that feedback needs to make it to the project otherwise we're just carrying technical debt.

My understanding is this patch facilitates transitioning to secure RBAC, and the ultimate goal is the settings are enabled by default. If we add service specific THT parameters now, they will need to be deprecated and removed after the transition period. So I vote in favor of using ExtraConfig, and leave it up to the services to work out requirements specific to their situation. There may be situations where a service would benefit from a THT parameter, but lets defer creating them until an actual use case arises.

proposing EnableSecureRBAC in [1]

1. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/783623

This is fine for testing but these need top level heat params with environment files to enable/disable to be merged.  *ExtraConfig should only be used as a last resort to config hiera data (e.g. by a customer) because they need to config something we don't already expose.  This being a feature should have a top level configuration.

If this is something Glance community is recommending, then can we ask them to own the default policy (create a sample yaml in their repo) and consume that file, rather than implementing these rules in tht layer ?

Yeah - this can probably be removed now that glance has done this upstream in the service defaults for the metadef API.

https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/f8551de8c9d660be3d6820918c1aaab0d235c98d

I'm reviewing this with the cinder folks and one question we're wondering is if we could just do this with a single variable:

  EnforceSecureRbac: true

Then each of the service api files for configuring the service would key off the same variable as opposed to individual variable (like how we enable TLS-e).

(It was me who initially suggested implementing the global parameter)
IMO it depends on whether we expect a use case where a user wants to/not to enforce SRBAC for specific services. If we expect SRBAC is enforced in all services at the same time then we can use the single parameter rather than adding multiple parameters. My initial expectation is that enforcement of SRBAC depends on the security policy of the deployment and would be something applied globally than than partially .

I am not against using a different boolean per service but I thought it'd be more user friendly to have a single parameter for all services and eventually let every service consume it to enable sRBAC

Can the cloud actually work with only some services configured for sRBAC?

So given the interactions between components (I can easily think of a simple scenario which involves at least nova, neutron, cinder, glance and probably others), does it really make sense to support the full matrix of combination where some services have SRBAC enabled and others don't? I think it makes things more complicated for no gain.

Yeah - that's fair.

I can rework this template and have it introduce a new global variable called EnforceSecureRbac, which will default to false.

Additionally, Kevin and I were working through the case where we set enforce_new_defaults: True and we don't think that's going to work without each service using the same common denominator (project personas for example). We knew this, but we're also waiting on development work in each of the services for them to use the right persona for service requests (e.g., neutron calling nova's API to update external events when creating an instance [0]).

I'll update this review to use the operator-facing policy variables to implement those changes (KeystonePolicies, NovaApiPolicies, etc...) The goal would be to get a deployment working with just the project personas initially and then introduce more personas as more services actually implement them.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/policies/server_external_events.py#L27
I think this should be something that is service specific provided that the cloud could work with only some services in rbac and others w/o rbac

The straight-forward case is if one service is calling a system-level API of another service that's configured to enforce secure RBAC with a project-scoped token, which will cause the request to fail.

Ok - one advantage of that is that it make it easier for operators to put a single service into enforcing secure RBAC mode (e.g., for a staging environment) to experiment with the new policies with minimal service changes.

I'm not sure how realistic is it for someone to use individual knobs in a production deployment, but for staging or test purposes it might be really useful and less invasive.

We'll move forward with that approach. Thanks, Alex.

That makes sense.

One thing to think about is that some of the services implement secure RBAC a little differently (e.g., glance's extra knob to turn on secure RBAC [0].) So I guess the thought was that they would just add a service specific option while they're in the process of proposing the necessary changes to enable secure RBAC.

I'm indifferent and I'll go with whatever the TripleO folks want to do.

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/configuration/glance_api.html#DEFAULT.enforce_secure_rbac
Apart from (human) operators, could there be any issue when services in mixed mode (some with srbac, others without) interact with each other?

If an operator understands what services are enforcing which personas, then they can switch accordingly (even if it is a pain, it's possible.) For example, if keystone is configured to enforce secure RBAC and cinder is not, then the operator needs to know they have to use the system-admin personas to create a new domain, but they need to use the project-admin persona to update storage pools in cinder.

Another key part of this answer is that even if the deployment is using mixed RBAC personas, the project-admin persona can't be given to regular end users until every service adopts secure RBAC.

So the short answer is yes it's possible, but it requires the operator to switch between administrative personas and they can't give project-admin to anyone while running in a mixed state.

wondering if we can split these out into their own 'per service' environment file and especially if that is better or worse from a UI point of view.

I don't expect Heat will have a problem with a 4500 line file but that aside, it is going to be a pain to work with for operators trying to find/adjust a particular policy for a given service.

it would mean your tool also takes a parameter which is $service_name. BUT i am not sure if this is in the end better or worse for the operator, i.e. they'd have to then specify multiple environment files for their secure-rbac policies
+1 for a per-service split. That would make the maintenance easier. Operator are already used to pass multiple env files within TripleO ecosystem (deploy, upgrade prepare, and so on).

I battled that same question for a while and I decided to propose it as a single file because of the following reasons (which I probably should have documented somewhere, like the commit message).

The way we intend this to work is that it will be a complete set of policy overrides that implement a baseline set of personas that will work across OpenStack services. Most deployments today have to implement some form of project-reader, and this allows that out of the box in addition to other consistencies. My goal is to describe those personas and encourage operators to use them if they meet or improve the security posture of their deployment. We don't intend users to create derivatives of this authorization model.

Another reason why I wanted to keep everything within a single file is that I don't expect this to be a long-term solution. Most, if not all, of the services upstream have some subset of these policies as their default. The hope is that we can continue working through changes necessary to implement system scope in Yoga [0]. That work will make this file obsolete if we can remove the overrides in favor of the service defaults upstream. The file, as is, provides a holistic view of *everything* that needs to change to offer at least some authorization consistency. I'm worried splitting these out to separate files will cause drift between the implementations, or some of them won't be updated if needed. Also, I think it raises the bar for operators consuming this change because they need to include more files in their deploy commands. For example, with multiple files, they could mistakenly omit cinder's overrides and think they've applied them but they haven't, allowing project-readers to create volumes when that's the opposite behavior in all the other services where the policies were overridden correctly.

FWIW - I have applied this environment to development deployments (using standalone and full deploys) and I didn't see any issues with heat applying an environment this large.

[0] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/yoga/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html

OK, if I'm understanding the concern, a base job in one repo might use, say 

 pre-run: playbooks/pre.yaml

and then a different project might have a file playbooks/pre.yaml, be inherited to the original-base job, not actually be using playbooks/pre.yaml in the job, but the job may now trigger if playbooks/pre.yaml in this repo is updated?

I think we can work-around this by just checking the playbook files we're adding here are coming from the same canonical project name.

config.yaml.message: While there are only two balancer modes for Ceph today (upmap and crush-compat) which lends towards a boolean option, there's the potential for alternatives in the future. I think we should change this option to `balancer-mode` and take as input a string parameter defining the mode (an enum would be better, but not an option).

The default value of upmap will cause a behavior change on upgrade of the charm, which is something we don't want. Leaving the default as an empty string will allow the ceph configuration to stay as is for existing deployments and will adopt whatever the default behavior is for Ceph.

Tee / John ?

I was looking at the page this is referring to:

https://docs.starlingx.io/dist_cloud/kubernetes/updating-docker-registry-credentials-on-a-subcloud.html

QUESTION on ABOVE PAGE ?
I don't believe you always need to do this ... i.e. after a normal subcloud install.

WHEN do you need to do this?
Can we say "when" you would need to do this at the top of this procedure ?

Updating registry credentials after a rehome is required if the credentials are different for the old central cloud's credentials and the new central cloud's credentials. Since we use the sysinv keystone user to interact with the registry, the credentials are almost guaranteed to be different. For all practical purposes, this is a required step.

I would say "When you want use the new System Controller’s sysinv service credentials for accessing registry.central".

As we require "openstack user password set" in a previous step, if we are using the admin password to access the registry.central before/after migrating a subcloud, we normally don't require this step. 

Would appreciate Tee/John's comments.

Suggested re-write:

When deleting image tags in the registry.local docker registry, care should be taken as the deletion of an <image-name:tag-name> will delete all tags under the specified <image-name> that have the same 'digest' as the specified <tag-name>.

I would use more generic image names
e.g.


jsmith/sampleimage-test:v1.0
jsmith/sampleimage-test:v1.1
jsmith/sampleimage-production:v1.0

shouldn't this say:

If the above three image:tags share the same digest in registry.local, then if 'jsmith/sampleimage-test:v1.1' is deleted, then "ALL" other tags under 'jsmith/sampleimage-test' that have the "SAME" digest (as jsmith/sampleimage-test:v1.1) are deleted.  That is, both 'jsmith/sampleimage-test:v1.0' and 'jsmith/sampleimage-test:v1.1' will be deleted, while 'jsmith/sampleimage-production:v1.0' would not be deleted.
I like Greg's suggestion here. Although unlikely, the original has a higher chance to be misinterpreted as "deleting v1.1 tag deletes the v1.0 tag instead. The v1.1 tag remains", which is incorrect.

sorry to be completely clear should probably have said here

<image-name><tag-name>

manifests/pxe.pp.message: Thanks, I happened to stumble upon that about fifteen minutes ago. Given the massive scale of the module, it does seem to make sense.

In current our modules, we define basic phases in the deps class. Mapping each resource to each phase helps us maintain dependency/timing of resources easily without maintaining huge number of dependencies among tons of resources.

https://github.com/openstack/puppet-ironic/blob/5eba05ee112568e44ae147e7c450bf4a4e124998/manifests/deps.pp#L6-L27

Basically we can map each resources to each phase, and if we need to put multiple items into one phases then we can explicitly define order/notification between these resources.
(For example here creation of systemd file and reload would happen in config phase, but these two requires ordering/notification)

doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst.message: I know you didn't change this from the previous, but I wonder if it's worth changing "performance" to "utilization". Overcommitting your CPU does not improve performance, it improves utilization in times where not all the instances are demanding all the resources they've been promised (or allocated). That also might further drive home the point about memory overcommit being purely a utilization hack.

doc/source/admin/overcommit.rst.message:
I assume you meant "processes" or "an instance process" or something?

Either way, using the word "process" is a bit KVM-specific, even though the same applies to any driver regardless of the mechanism it uses, so maybe just say

 "relies on instances not running at 100% CPU utilization"

?

I don't think this is really the right way to communicate this. First, it's UNIX specific, so not really relevant for the vmware backend, certainly not Xen (while we have it), and not for hyper-v. Further, a high load average doesn't necessarily mean that we're not getting all our work done, nor does it mean that we're causing the average to increase. Technically any overcommit over 1.0 is promising this, so "Setting overcommit too high" also makes it sound like there's  some value you can set it to, greater than 1.0 that won't result in the consequences you lay out.

I think I'd just say that setting it too high will cause even instances not demanding 100% CPU to be starved of CPU cycles as there is more competition for those available host CPU cycles.

In all cases, at least with KVM, it's a race against time as any Linux guest that reads $MEMORY_MB data from disk will inflate its own page cache to the size of memory it *thinks* it has. I feel like it might be good to say that in here so people don't think "oh well, I want my guests to appear to have 128GB of ram even though it's just a wordpress instance, and I'll never use all that."

Is it worth noting that the default memory overcommit ratio is (possibly surprisingly) set to 1.5 as opposed to the arguably more intuitive value of 1.0?

(for historical reasons apparently, now lost in the mists of time)

Would it make sense to provide a rule of thumb on what we mean by sufficient swap space?

e.g. circa 4Gb for the host OS plus circa 1Gb per guest for the QEMU process overhead plus the memory overcommit ratio times physical memory?

Yes, we need to state a rule. The rule should be that there should be at least as much swap space as overcommitment. So, if you have 8GB of physical RAM and are overcommitting at 1.5, you need at least 4GB of swap. On Linux especially, you'll need more than that both for the system itself and the fact that swap accounting itself takes up some memory. I'm not sure that we really need "GB per guest" which is also hard to quantify since you don't typically know how many guests will land on a system. Something like "enough to cover you overcommitment plus 10%" might be easy.

I feel like there needs to be something more here, or in the last paragraph. You don't want people to think that using sparse files is enough, nor that if they run like this and "it works for a while" that everything is good. I know you mention "continuous monitoring" in the last paragraph, but it seems like we should mention something about how, in general, even sparse formats _will_ grow to the full size of the virtual disk over time, making any disk overcommit just a bet on how long it will take for that to happen, even with less than 100% guest disk utilization.

can we rename the container as well? 

 - servers: servers_optional_for_some_reason
   - servers

?

WELL ... You can't do the syntax you just said:

  - servers: servers_optional_for_some_reason

Is

  [{"servers": "servers_optional_for_some_reason"}]

while

  - servers:
    - servers
    - name: name

Is

  [{"servers": [
      "servers",
      {"name": "servers_optional_for_some_reason"},
  ]]

In the form:

  - servers:
    - name: name
    - name2: name2

There's nowhere to put the parameter name that describes the top level entry. This stab was "put a scalar in list position 0 that holds the value"

I also thought about:

  - servers:
    .parameter: server_param
    name: name
    name: name2

But that felt weirder ... do you think it would be clearer?

when I first saw the proposed syntax, I felt the first element weird as it is a different format from others.

I think it is a good idea to use a special keyword like '.parameter' as it clarifies the context.

Another idea is to use one more hierarchy, but it may be too much.

  - servers:
       parameter: servers
       sub_elements:
         - name: name
         - name2: name2
Yeah, if it's an array type, do a different output.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This says ptgbot but the records you created are for ptg instead. Which did you want?

zones/opendev.org/zone.db.message: This target doesn't seem to exist. ptg.openstack.org points to eavesdrop01.openstack.org in DNS but I think that server has been cleaned up in favor of eavesdrop01.opendev.org. Do you maybe want to make the target here eavesdrop01.opendev.org?

since we'll be running this on eavesdrop01.opendev.org, ptgbot (not 01) should be a CNAME to eavesdrop01

this will also want _acme-challenge.ptgbot CNAME entry as well, so we can get a cert to cover it.

author.name: Jeremy Stanley
author.status: missing, presumed fed

zones/opendev.org/zone.db.message: Okay, per the child change, it looks like what you want here is "ptgbot IN CNAME eavesdrop01" (you can leave off the opendev.org domains because this is already in the zone for opendev.org so that domain is assumed for any relative names in the file).

author.name: Jeremy Stanley
author.status: missing, presumed fed

zones/opendev.org/zone.db.message: Other way around... this should be ptg IN CNAME eavesdrop01 (basically saying that if you ask for ptg.opendev.org then you'll be told to use eavesdrop01.opendev.org instead).

author.name: Jeremy Stanley
author.status: missing, presumed fed

zones/opendev.org/zone.db.message: Don't need these CAA records, since eavesdrop01 (what we're CNAME'd to) already has them. In fact, you cant have other records with the same name as a CNAME record because then the nameserver doesn't know which set of records it should respond with, so this causes the error you see loading the zone.

author.name: Jeremy Stanley
author.status: missing, presumed fed

zones/opendev.org/zone.db.message: This record is necessary, though here you have ptgbot instead of ptg. It should be consistent with what you put in the CNAME (and what the Web server is configured to respond with), per my comment on the commit message.
